greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Least odd prime p such that 2*n - p = sigma(k) for some k > 0, or 0 if such an odd prime p does not exist, where sigma(k) is the sum of all (positive) divisors of k.
comment: Conjecture: a(n) > 0 for all n > 1. Moreover, if n > 180 is not among 284, 293, 371, 542, 788, 1274, then 2*n can be written as p + sigma(m^2), where p is an odd prime and m is a positive integer.
See also part (i) of the conjecture in A233654.
Note that if sigma(k) is odd, then the order of k at each odd prime must be even, and hence k has the form m^2 or 2*m^2, where m is a positive integer.
We have verified part (i) of the conjecture for n up to 10^9.
link: Zhi-Wei Sun, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
example: a(2) = 3 since 2*2 = 3 + sigma(1), but 2*2 = 2 + sigma(k) for no k > 0.
results.author: _Zhi-Wei Sun_, Dec 15 2013
